questions.question: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER with a nose bleed secondary to trauma. The bleedingstarted an hour ago and has not stopped. Where is the bleed most likely to be from?
Where is Little's area situated?
questions.explanation: Little's area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule.

questions.question: A worried mother brought her 4-year-old son to the ER with complaints of a nose bleed. Onexamination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach's plexus. Which of the followingarteries does not contribute to its formation?
questions.explanation: The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach's plexus.Kiesselbach's plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little's area (anteroinferior part of theseptum).The contributing arteries are as follows:• Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branchof the external carotid artery.•Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. Thefacial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.•• Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

questions.question: Identify the artery of epistaxis in the given image.
questions.explanation: The structure marked 3 is the sphenopalatine artery, which is also known as the artery of epistaxis. It is called the artery of epistaxis because the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is derived from it. It is also the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis. Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows: 1 Anterior ethmoidal artery, 2 Posterior ethmoidal artery, 4 Greater palatine artery. Blood supply of the nasal septum: Internal carotid artery, Ophthalmic artery, Anterior ethmoidal artery, Kiesselbach's plexus, Septal branch, Superior labial artery, Greater palatine artery, Facial artery, External carotid artery, OMARROW Posterior ethmoidal artery, Sphenoid sinus, Sphenopalatine artery, Maxillary artery.

questions.question: Which of the following marked structures is a branch of the internal carotid artery?
questions.explanation: The structure marked 1 is the anterior ethmoidal artery, which is a branch of the ophthalmicdivision of the internal carotid artery.Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:2 - Sphenopalatine artery3 - Greater palatine artery4 - Superior labial artery2, 3 and 4 are derived from branches of the external carotid artery.The nasal septum is supplied by branches of both internal and external carotid arteries.330Blood supply of the nasal septumInternal carotid arteryAnterior ethmoidalarteryKiesselbach'splexusSeptal branch↑Superior labialartery↑Facial arteryOphthalmic arteryGreaterpalatinearteryExternal carotidarteryOMARROWPosterior ethmoidalarterySphenoid sinusSphenopalatinearteryMaxillary artery

questions.question: A 40-year-old male patient with a history of uncontrolled, chronic hypertension was rushed tothe casualty after he had an episode of coughing out frank blood. On further evaluation, adiagnosis of posterior epistaxis, secondary to hypertension, was made. What is the site of theblood vessel most likely to be involved in this case?
questions.explanation: The most common cause for posterior epistaxis is arterial and the vessel involved is thesphenopalatine artery. It is located in the posterior end of the middle turbinate.Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus located in the posterior end of the inferior turbinate and isalso sometimes implicated in epistaxis associated with systemic conditions such as hypertensionand coagulopathy. However, it only accounts for about 5-10% of all nose bleeds.Note: Most common vessel involved in both anterior and posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatineartery and not Woodruff's plexus.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of epistaxis in children?
questions.explanation: Microtrauma due to nose pricking is the most common cause of epistaxis in children.Other common aetiological associations include upper respiratory tract infections.Note: In children presenting with recurrent epistaxis, bleeding disorders, hereditary hemorrhagictelangiectasia, and tumors, etc. have to be ruled out.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of epistaxis in elderly patients?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of epistaxis in elderly patients is idiopthic.Other causes are:• Trauma• Coagulopathy331.-Tumor high suspicion in elderly patients presenting with epistaxis• Infection• Medication•Note: Due to the failure of studies to establish a causal relationship between hypertension andepistaxis, hypertension is now considered an associated risk factor and not a cause.Risk factors associated with epistaxis are weather changes and alcohol consumption.

questions.question: A 4-year-old child presents with persistent unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge which isblood-stained. Which of the following is the most likely cause?325
questions.explanation: In a child presenting with persistent unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge, which isblood-stained, the most likely cause is a foreign body.Foreign body can cause unilateral nasal obstruction and subsequent superimposed infectionwhich causes malodorous discharge. It may often be blood-stained.Option B: Atrophic rhinitis usually starts at puberty and mainly presents with nasal obstructionand foul smell from the nose. Epistaxis occurs only after the removal of crusts.Option C: Epistaxis is a rare manifestation of polyps.Option D: Unilateral nasal angiofibroma also presents as painless, progressive unilateralnasal obstruction, often associated with epistaxis and rhinorrhea. But it is more common in theadolescent age group.

questions.question: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below?Pinch nostrils

options.D: Valsalva maneuvreSit and leanforward slightlyBreathe throughmouth

questions.explanation: The given image shows Trotter's method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a littleforward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step tocontrol epistaxis.Other options:Option A: Epley's maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal PositionalVertigo).332Epley's maneuverReturn patient to upright.seated position withneck flexed for 20-30 secondsWith patient seated on the table.turn head 45° toward the affected sidewhile extending the neck.ColitGOLay the patient down keepingthe head rotated andextend the neck 10" to 20"depending on the patient'sability and comfort. Hold thisposition for 20-30 secondsor until nystagmus ceTum head another 90″rolling the body towardthe unaffected sicle.Hold this position for 20-30seconds or until nystagmusor vertigo ceasesTurn head 90” toward theunaffected side. Hold this positionfor 20-30 seconds or untilnystagmus or vertigo ceases.©MARROWOption C: McGovern's technique is used in choanal atresia. A feeding nipple with a large holeprovides a good oral airway.OMARROWOption D: Valsalva maneuver is performed by forceful attempted exhalation against a closed noseand mouth. It is used as a test of cardiac function and autonomic nervous control of the heart, orto clear the ears and sinuses.

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman came to the casualty with a history of an episode of spontaneousepistaxis yesterday night. On examination, her BP was 200/110, and there was no activebleeding from the nose. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managingthis case?
questions.explanation: The most appropriate next step is observation and blood pressure management as there is noactive bleeding from the nose.333

questions.question: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presented with a history of recurrent episodes of spontaneous nose bleeds over the past two weeks, each requiring medical attention. After evaluating the patient, the ENT surgeon recommended endoscopic artery ligation to prevent further episodes. Which of the following arteries is most commonly ligated in this procedure?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of refractory posterior epistaxis. The artery that is most commonly ligated in a case of refractory posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatine artery. Posterior epistaxis is most commonly seen in older age groups. The bleeding is spontaneous, often due to hypertension, and is severe, requiring hospitalization. Refractory epistaxis is defined as recurrent or persistent bleeding after appropriate packing or multiple episodes of epistaxis during a short period, each requiring medical attention. Sphenopalatine artery ligation gives high success in the control of refractory posterior bleeding. Therefore, transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is the preferred method. It is ligated at the sphenopalatine foramen situated 1 cm behind the posterior end of the middle turbinate. Anterior epistaxis: Children and young adults. Most common type. Age: Incidence: Cause: Trauma. Site: Little's area, anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. Bleeding: Mild, can be controlled by local pressure or nasal packing. Posterior epistaxis: >40 years. Less common. Spontaneous; often due to hypertension or arteriosclerosis. Site: Posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity; difficult to localize. Bleeding: Severe, often requires hospitalization and posterior nasal packing. Blood supply of the nasal septum: Internal carotid artery, anterior ethmoidal artery, Kiesselbach's plexus, septal branch, superior labial artery, ophthalmic artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, sphenoid sinus, sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery, maxillary artery, facial artery, external carotid artery.

questions.question: As a first-year resident, you have scrubbed in to assist for a maxillary artery ligationprocedure on a patient with intractable epistaxis. After opening the posterior wall of themaxillary sinus, the surgeon asks you to ligate the maxillary artery. Where would you ligatethe artery at?
questions.explanation: The maxillary artery is ligated at the pterygopalatine fossa (sphenopalatine fossa) situated behindthe maxillary sinus's posterior wall.The internal maxillary artery is accessed transantrally via a Caldwell-Luc approach. After theposterior sinus wall is removed, the internal maxillary artery and its terminal branches areidentified and clipped. The posterior sinus wall is then packed with Gelfoam, and thegingivobuccal incision is closed. More recently, transoral and transnasal endoscopic approacheshave also been described.Maxillary artery within the maxillary sinusMaxillarysinusOMARROWPterygopalatinefossaNMaxillaryarteryPosteriorwall of themaxillary sinus

questions.question: Which artery among the following could be the source of bleeding in a case of epistaxis notcontrolled by external carotid artery ligation?
questions.explanation: Ethmoidal artery can cause epistaxis not controlled by external carotid artery ligation.335The ethmoidal artery is a branch of internal carotid artery, whereas sphenopalatine, greaterpalatine and facial artery are branches of the external carotid artery. Hence if the bleeding is notcontrolled by external carotid artery ligation, the subsequent step would be to ligate the ethmoidalartery.Epistaxis may be classified as anterior or posterior epistaxis.Little's area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. Itis the site of epistaxis in 90% of the cases.Four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called the Kiesselbach's plexus. This areais exposed to the drying effect of inspiratory current and to fingernail trauma and is the usual sitefor epistaxis in children and young adults.The four contributing arteries are as follows:•⚫ Septal branch of sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which inturn is a branch of the external carotid artery.•Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. Thefacial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.• Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.SiteAnterior epistaxisLittle's area or anterior part oof the lateral wallAgeCauseChildren, young adultsUsually traumaBleedi Mild, easily controlled with conservative measures (pressure, anterior nasal pack)ngPosterior epistaxisPosterosuperior part of the nasal cavity, or difficult to localize>40 years of ageSpontaneous, due to hypertension or IHDSevere requires hospitalisation and posterior nasal packBlood supply of the nasal septumInternal carotid arteryOphthalmic arteryAnterior ethmoidalarteryKiesselbach'splexusSeptal branch↑Superior labialartery↑Posterior ethmoidalarterySphenoid sinusGreaterpalatinearterySphenopalatine.arteryMaxillary arteryFacial arteryExternal carotidarteryOMARROW336The stepwise management of epistaxis:•.Pinching the noseHippocratic or Trotter's method• Cauterisation• Anterior nasal packing• Posterior nasal packing•Endoscopic Cauterisation•• Ligation• EmbolizationLigation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point. The recommendedhierarchy of ligation to be followed is Sphenopalatine artery °Internal maxillaryartery °External carotid artery ° Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.Ethmoidal vessels are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external ethmoid (Lynch)incision.Lynch incisionMARROWLynch incisionOW

questions.question: 327Which of the following vessels would you never ligate for the control of recurrentspontaneous epistaxis?
questions.explanation: Internal carotid artery is not ligated for controlling epistaxis due to the high percentage ofcerebral complications and mortality.•Ligation of the following arteries is done in epistaxis control :Trans nasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL)• If not controlled, maxillary artery ligation•If still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation337• In case, bleeding site is superior to the level of middle turbinate, then anterior and posteriorethmoidal vessels should be ligated.338
